column4: I was at a lan the other day, and, as such, using Windows. Some kid brought a virus and, due to it really screwing me over, I had to format. Since the format however, GRUb won't allow me to boot into windows at all, instead presenting me an 'unknown partition type' error. Out of desperation, I formatted Ubuntu thinking that Grub would detect it as normal. This wasn't the case, as nothing was detected. So please, can somebody shed some light on t
he situation? As I have another lan to go to.
lan?
what is a lan?
yess
yes, and just now, reinstalled ubuntu
ya, did windows ever boot after the install?
you could have just reinstalled grub.
there is a menu, and a menu-xdg
killall gnome-panel will also work likely.
nope, trying to do it through smeg
should i just restart x?
didn't work, thanks for the help anyway
hm...using gnome?
your method intrigues me, eloborate
if you are using gnome, there is a thing that runs with gnome called gnome-volume-manager, and it automounts(or is set to taht by default, anyhow) all shizzes that you connect.
if you are not using gnome, well, you could run the volume-manager in a terminal, it should work.
no such luck here
using gnome, but it did not automount
yes. install imagemagick for a start.
already installed]
and now, "sleep X; import --root blah.png" for a png screenshot, where X is the number of seconds of delay. sleep is the delay command in GNU.
